qna.a: The business must be small by SBA size standards and a for-profit business.   SBA will look at repayment ability, good character, management capability, and collateral. For loans made with SBA’s assistance, the Agency has credit and policy requirements that all applicants must meet. Among those are an adequate equity investment in the business and evidence of ability to repay the loan from earnings.  With the exception of some child care businesses, all businesses must be for-profit.

alt.ssml: <speak>The business applying for a loan must be a small for-profit business (with the exception of some child care businesses) that has good repayment ability, character, management capability, and collateral. For more information go to: </speak>

qna.a: The Small Business Administration extends financial assistance to for-profit small businesses through its lending partners, such as banks, certified development companies, and micro loan intermediaries.  The Small Business Administration SBA itself does not offer direct lending.  Most SBA loan programs are unable to provide 100% financing.  Everything in this process is handled between you and the lender.

alt.ssml: <speak>The Small Business Administration extends financial assistance to for-profit small businesses</speak>

qna.a: Some of the most frequent reasons a business will be small and not show up as small in SAM are: The company has been listed as tax exempt, they are a non-profit business, they did not submit the correct revenue or number of employees, and they are not small for the specific NAICS Codes they have selected.

qna.a: The U. S. Small Business Administration (SBA) provides low-interest, long-term disaster loans to businesses of all sizes, private non-profit organizations, homeowners, and renters to repair or replace uninsured/underinsured disaster damaged property. SBA disaster loans offer an affordable way for individuals and businesses to recover from declared disasters.
